page.title: 03ECOLOGY (UPPER FROYLE)
page.content: Upper Froyle is in a{conservation area which means that it cannot be altered very much without special planning permission through the East Hants District Council at Petersfield. If trees die they must be replanted but the others may not be cut down unless they are dangerous. Although the land has been widely farmed for centuries, some natural woodland and downland remains. There are fewer wild flowers now than were recorded by the WI for their Scrapbook in 1952. {The wild {tulip grew in Froyle}but it became rare and disappeared with the making of the dual carriageway.{ Nightingales {still sing in the woods.} Our school has planted an evergreen oak, maple, silver birch and hawthorn trees in the school grounds in recent years.
